cellularAutomata.artificialLife.chromosome
Interface Chromosome

public interface Chromosome

A chromosome for an artificial life simulation.

Author:
David Bahr

Method Detail

clone

java.lang.Object clone()
Returns an exact copy of the chromosome. This should be a newly instantiated chromosome (and should never return "this" because that would not be a copy). Any instance variables within the chromosome should also be new instances (in other words, those variables should not be passed into the constructor of the new chromosome unless they are primitive types and not Objects).

Cloning is necessary when selecting chromosomes repeatedly for the next generation's population. Without cloning, an alteration to one Phenotype's chromosome could unintentially alter another Phenotype's chromosome (because they happen to be built from the same chromosome).

A simple solution is for this method to return new ChildChromosome(this.toString()); assuming that the child of this class has a constructor that takes a string.

Returns:
A copy of the chromosome.

equals

boolean equals(java.lang.Object obj)
The specified object is equal to this chromosome if (1) they are members of the same class and (2) they return the same string representation.

Overrides:
equals in class java.lang.Object
Parameters:
obj - The object to which this chromosome is being compared.

getGene

Chromosome getGene(int start,
                   int end)
Gets a subset of the chromosome (a gene).

Parameters:
start - The beginning position of the gene (inclusive).
end - The ending position of the gene (exclusive).
Returns:
The gene as a new Chromosome (of equal or shorter length).

toString

java.lang.String toString()
A String representation of the chromosome (for example, "00010110").

Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object
Returns:
The chromosome as a string (for example a string of bits).
